intro: Plagiobothrys hispidus, commonly known as the hairy bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, showy flowers and distinctive seed pods. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and shrublands. Its hairy stems and leaves are adapted to reduce water loss in arid environments. The species is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological niche.
